Text:
Fortunately, Microsoft's stance on this issue has changed. MSVC++ version 12.0 (part of Visual Studio 2013) [added support](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/hh409293.aspx) for

* _Bool
* Compound literals.
* Designated initializers.
* Mixing declarations with code.

[Standard library support](http://blogs.msdn.com/b/vcblog/archive/2013/07/19/c99-library-support-in-visual-studio-2013.aspx) has also been updated.

You can check the [`_MSC_VER` macro](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/70013/how-to-detect-if-im-compiling-code-with-visual-studio-2008) for values greater or equal than 1800 to see if these features are supported.

Fortunately, Microsoft's stance on this issue has changed. MSVC++ version 12.0 (part of Visual Studio 2013) [added support](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/hh409293(v=vs.120).aspx) for

* _Bool
* Compound literals.
* Designated initializers.
* Mixing declarations with code.

[Standard library support](http://blogs.msdn.com/b/vcblog/archive/2013/07/19/c99-library-support-in-visual-studio-2013.aspx) has also been updated and is [mostly complete](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/hh409293.aspx#BK_CRT) in MSVC 14.0 (Visual Studio 2015).

You can check the [`_MSC_VER` macro](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/70013/how-to-detect-if-im-compiling-code-with-visual-studio-2008) for values greater than or equal to 1800 to see if these features are supported.

Fortunately, Microsoft's stance on this issue has changed. MSVC++ version 12.0 (part of Visual Studio 2013) [added support](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/hh409293(v=vs.120).aspx) for

* _Bool
* Compound literals.
* Designated initializers.
* Mixing declarations with code.

[Standard library support](http://blogs.msdn.com/b/vcblog/archive/2013/07/19/c99-library-support-in-visual-studio-2013.aspx) has also been updated and is [mostly complete](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/hh409293.aspx#BK_CRT) in MSVC 14.0 (Visual Studio 2015).

You can check the [`_MSC_VER` macro](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/70013/how-to-detect-if-im-compiling-code-with-visual-studio-2008) for values greater than or equal to 1800 to see if these features are supported.

Things that earlier versions already supported:

* `//` style comments.
* Flexible array members.
* Variadic macros (at least partially).

Things that are still missing:

* Variable length arrays.
* Support for the `inline` keyword (you can use `__inline`, but semantics might be slightly different).
* Support for the `restrict` keyword (you might be able to use `__restrict`).
* Type-generic math functions from `tgmath.h`.

* _Bool
* Compound literals.
* Designated initializers.
* Mixing declarations with code.
* `__func__` macro.

[Standard library support](http://blogs.msdn.com/b/vcblog/archive/2013/07/19/c99-library-support-in-visual-studio-2013.aspx) has also been updated and is [mostly complete](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/hh409293.aspx#BK_CRT) in MSVC 14.0 (Visual Studio 2015).

* `_Bool` type.
* Compound literals.
* Designated initializers.
* Mixing declarations with code.
* `__func__` macro.

[Standard library support](http://blogs.msdn.com/b/vcblog/archive/2013/07/19/c99-library-support-in-visual-studio-2013.aspx) has also been updated and is [mostly complete](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/hh409293.aspx#BK_CRT) in MSVC 14.0 (Visual Studio 2015).

Things that earlier versions already supported:

* `//` style comments.
* `long long` type.
* Flexible array members.
* Variadic macros (at least partially).

Things that are still missing:

* Variable length arrays.
* Support for the `inline` keyword (you can use `__inline`, but semantics might be slightly different).
* Support for the `restrict` keyword (you might be able to use `__restrict`).
* Type-generic math functions from `tgmath.h`.
* `_Complex` type.

Fortunately, Microsoft's stance on this issue has changed. MSVC++ version 12.0 (part of Visual Studio 2013) [added support](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/hh409293(v=vs.120).aspx) for

* `_Bool` type.
* Compound literals.
* Designated initializers.
* Mixing declarations with code.
* `__func__` macro.

[Standard library support](http://blogs.msdn.com/b/vcblog/archive/2013/07/19/c99-library-support-in-visual-studio-2013.aspx) has also been updated and is [mostly complete](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/hh409293.aspx#BK_CRT) in MSVC 14.0 (Visual Studio 2015).

You can check the [`_MSC_VER` macro](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/70013/how-to-detect-if-im-compiling-code-with-visual-studio-2008) for values greater than or equal to 1800 to see if these features are supported.

Things that earlier versions already supported (I think since at least MSVC 7.1 / Visual Studio 2003):

* `//` style comments.
* `long long` type.
* Flexible array members (Microsoft called them "unsized arrays").
* Variadic macros (at least partially).

Things that are still missing:

* Variable length arrays (optional in C11).
* Support for the `inline` keyword (you can use `__inline`, but semantics might be slightly different).
* Support for the `restrict` keyword (you might be able to use `__restrict`).
* Type-generic math functions from `tgmath.h`.
* `_Complex` type.
